title.rendered: Dutch Police uncovers crypto used in alleged money laundering

content.rendered:
• The Dutch police force website reports the arrest of the criminal
  • It is believed that this person updated their Electrum wallet with malicious code.

Central Netherlands cybercrime detectives have detained a 39-year-old Veenendaal man on suspicion of using cryptocurrency fraud to launder tens of millions of euros. According to the authorities, the suspect amassed his cryptocurrency assets using a fraudulent variant of the cryptocurrency wallet Electrum.

The Dutch police force’s website reported the criminal’s arrest. The research indicates that he routinely exchanged vast amounts of stolen Bitcoin for Monero and, conversely, on the decentralized market Bisq. Therefore, it required a thorough investigation to discover his fraudulent activities.

Nefarious methods

Local law enforcement officers traced the 39-year-old criminal’s BTC operations back to him thanks to a cooperative investigation with the central cybercrime squad. He was in the town of Veenendaal when he was brought into custody.

During his fraud, the authorities thought he had laundered cryptocurrencies valued at several million euros. As a result, law officials searched his residence and seized various “data carriers” that they believed may be helpful in their investigations in addition to taking that money.

This person is suspected of stealing cryptocurrency from other users’ wallets using a fraudulent Electrum wallet software update. This open-source, free application can be used to maintain and access cryptocurrency holdings.

As per the reports by the Dutch police:

“The money was confiscated after the spamming distribution of fake Electrum software utilizing malicious servers.”

Before releasing him, the officials detained the man for a few days. But authorities are still looking for him concerning a multi-million dollar cryptocurrency crime. In areas where digital assets are widespread, cryptocurrency fraud schemes commonly appear.
